@junrao @jkreps @guozhangwang @ijuma @mumrah @sriramsub @d3fmacro : Guys, this PR has been open for a long time. It has been reviewed by @norwood . I'd really appreciate if one of you can take a look and merge this.

The log I checked was on the client side and I am sure that the code I modified was called by the client. I forget if I checked the log on the server side or not, but it is clear that the connection is closed by some reason on the client side.

About `assertj`, seems it does not add more asserting functionalities that junit cannot provide? Is there any specific reasons you want to add a new dependency jar into Kafka?

`BlockingChannel.scala` is used by both the old Scala consumer as well as the server, so adding this log entry will affect both the client and the server.

In the new consumer available since 0.9, we used a new Java class `Selector` for NIO, and I checked its source code: for similar connection dropped issue, it will indeed log a debug entry. Would you like to take a look at the new consumer and see if you are willing to upgrade to that client?
Merged to trunk. Thanks.

@dguy Thanks for pointing it out. It was a mistake. Please check I have fixed it.

> Is there any specific reasons you want to add a new dependency jar into Kafka?

It's a test-dependency, which incorporates functionality of `junit` and `hamcrest-matchers`. As for me, I love the "builder-like" syntax for writing tests - allows applying multiple checks for a single value. Also no mess with "actual" and "expected" values (which one is the first, and which one is a second). As a bonus, it supports Java 8 constructions starting from 3.x.x version.

But it's still just a suggestion.

@mjsax it would be useful to have an idea of what the overall plan is. It looks like `InternalTopologyBuilder` is basically what `TopologyBuilder` is currently. Then the new `TopologyBuilder` just delegates and only provides an api that is sensible to the PAPI. So far so good.
I'm not entirely sure what value `InternalKStreamBuilder` is going to provide? Why not just have `KStreamBuilder` depend on `InternalTopologyBuilder`? I think eventually we need all of the information on the topology in one place, i.e., `InternalTopologyBuilder`, such that it can be used by `StreamThread` to build the `ProcessorTopology`.

@huyanping Just to clarify, in the new consumer client it is still possible that the connections are dropped, but the new client's internal NIO channel implementation will log it.

Since I cannot close this PR myself, could you close it then?

> But it's still just a suggestion.

Personally I'd try to avoid growing dependencies, both runtime and test unless it is necessary. For `assertj` I found it provides some syntax sugar and more clear argument semantics but not providing any asserting functionalities that `junit` and `harmcrest` already provides.
Rebase on trunk

Thanks for the patch, a couple of meta comments:

1. `ChangeSerde` is used internally only and not exposed to users, so we do not need to add no-arg constructor to it.

2. For `WindowedSerde`, inner serde is required, so if it is not passed in constructor, which is possible, we need to construct it in `configure` function, which will be auto-triggered when the instance is created by reflection. You can take a look at `StringSerde` class as a semi-related reference. Personally I'm thinking the inner serde could be again constructed via reflection from a passed class type string, and then assigned to `inner`.

You are right about `InternalTopologyBuilder` and `TopologyBuilder`.

Currently, `KStreamBuilder` extends `TopologyBuilder` but IMHO this abstraction is not the best one because `KStreamBuilder` offers a completely new way (ie, DSL) to specify a topology and thus, it should only *use* `TopologyBuilder` but not extend it -- hence, `KStreamBuilder`now has a member variable of type `TopologyBuilder`. (There is not need to have low level PAPI methods in `KStreamBuilder`.)

Furthermore, currently `TopologyBuilder` offers some helper methods that are DSL specific and should not be part of `TopologyBuilder`. Thus, I moved them from `(Internal)TopologyBuilder` into a new internal help class `InternalKStreamBuilder`.

There a still some abstractions that are messy -- the final goal would be to have a clear separation of `TopologyBuilder` and the DSL -- if we achieve this, we can also remove `InternalKStreamBuilder` and put its helper methods as private into `KStreamBuilder` -- right now, the abstractions are still leaky in this PR with this regard.

I agree, that in final refactoring, runtime should be have any idea if a topology was build via `TopologyBuilder` or `KStreamBuilder` -- this is not the case right now and not completely fixed by this PR yet -- it's still WIP.
